data.title: nod6b: Map preview too far to the right
data.body: Steal the Detonator (b): when selecting (a) and (c) the map is further to the left (as it is with all the other missions), but when selecting (b) it suddenly jumps to the right

data.title: Moved the sequence image check to RenderSprites level
data.body: This detected several unnecessary RenderSprites traits in the Tiberian Sun mods. Split from https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7709.

data.title: Fix tesla zaps being visible under the fog
data.body: Fixes #8291 pretty much the same way as #6304 fixed the Obelisk laser zaps.

data.title: Intervention: losing MCV loaded in transport doesn't fail mission
data.body:
Version: Playtest 20150524
Mission: Intervention (Red Alert)

Steps to reproduce:

1) Proceed normally by building a power plant, ore refinery, naval yard and transport.
2) Load the MCV into the transport.
3) Get the transport sunk while carrying the MCV by heading towards the turrets in the top left.

This should fail the mission but doesn't.
## <bountysource-plugin>

Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/18875100-intervention-losing-mcv-loaded-in-transport-doesn-t-fail-mission?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F36085&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github)** We accept bounties via [Bountysource](https://www.bountysource.com/?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F36085&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github).
</bountysource-plugin>

data.title: Enemy shock troops electric shock is visible through fog of war.
data.body: This is in newest release (04242015) of RA.

data.title: Give D2k its own mission browser
data.body:
Since D2k has different requirements about the size and shape of some components than RA, it gets its own mission browser.
Feel free to compare with bleed and decide which looks better ;)

data.title: Speed up PremultiplyAlpha
data.body: The bugfix in #8248 means all line rendering requires pre-multiplying the line colours. This mitigates the perf impact for rendering solid colours.

data.title: Update gdi05a mission preview image.
data.body: Fixes #8287.

data.title: 5a mission in TD preview
data.body:
Hi guys, I am not able to help you with coding, so I will try and catch out and repair small bugs/irregularities in game. 

I played TD missions when I noticed that GDI 5a mission map has badly cut edges, so I used 4b map as alpha channel and cleared it up a bit.
![map](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12610736/7884846/ea76163a-0620-11e5-852a-5c1511b2d7f9.png)
I am not sure where to put it so please, use it as you wish, you can discard it completely if you think its unimportant.

You can see improvement here.
![5a](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12610736/7884881/14102e40-0621-11e5-8c33-2537cb98ee14.png)

Cheers

data.title: Add a lint check for DeathAnimations
data.body:
Adds a lint check whether each actor with `WithDeathAnimation` define a death animation for every warhead that can kill it.
The second commit will go away once #8283 is merged.

Closes #8270.

data.title: Enable compiler optimizations
data.body:
Adds a release config to the solution with optimizations enabled, and changes the makefile to use these flags too.

We should test this a fair amount to ensure it doesn't introduce any desyncs. I suggest we collect some replays from the latest release (ideally from a variety of OSes) and have some contributors replay them using an optimized build on their system. Any new desyncs would indicate we have a problem.

I don't think the risk of desyncs is too high though, I present some more detailed reasoning below.

---

There's been a worry for some time that enabling compiler optimizations might provoke desyncs due to differences in how the mono and MS runtimes might optimize things. However, it seems things are less risky than we thought because it appears that both runtimes are already applying runtime optimizations!.

We currently build with the `-optimize-` flag passed to the compiler, which disables compiler optimizations.

The compiler doesn't really do any optimizations though - the real optimization happens at runtime when the jitter generates the actual code your machine runs.

If you build via MSBuild and run the binary on Windows, it appears the MS runtime uses the compile time flag to decide if it's going to optimize or not.

The mono runtime has a separate command line flag that control optimizations at runtime. If you run a binary (built by either MSBuild or mono), the performance is dependant on this flag, and the compiler flag is essentially irrelevant.

@Phrohdoh was kind enough to demonstrate. I get similar results on Windows (running an MSBuild binary with compiler optimizations disabled).

Unspecified flag: Run with the default set of optimizations.
`--optimize=all`: Run with all optimizations.
`--optimize=-all`: Run with no optimizations.

```
[20:01] RoosterDragon   Run OpenRA via mono with a couple of different flags and see what the ticks times are like on the shellmap.
[20:01] Phroh|orca  Which flags? Which mod?
[20:01] RoosterDragon   Let's say RA since it has a busy shellmap.
[20:01] RoosterDragon   Please try these three:
[20:02] RoosterDragon   'mono OpenRA.Game.exe'
[20:02] RoosterDragon   'mono --optimize=all OpenRA.Game.exe'
[20:02] RoosterDragon   'mono --optimize=-all OpenRA.Game.exe'
[20:02] RoosterDragon   Just eyeball the numbers.
[20:03] Phroh|orca  12.2-15.4 for mono openra.game.exe
[20:03] Phroh|orca  ~700 ticks
[20:04] Phroh|orca  12-15.6 for optimize=all
[20:05] Phroh|orca  20-34 for optimize=-all
```

This would explain why the AppVeyor build was so much slower in #8153. Mono has been optimizing all along but the MS runtime was not. In #8187, we reintroduced a mono-built binary to Windows. I speculate that the binary built by mono does not contain a "don't optimize" flag that the MS runtime understands, and so it optimizes by default. I think this because an optimized MSBuild runs at a similar speed as the mono build.

Anyway, assume the hopefully reasonable speculation to explain the observed performance of everything is correct, then in reality we're deploying a mono build with compiler optimizations disabled, but which both runtimes were optimizing at runtime anyway.

Therefore, if we can bring back a release config:
- We could consider using AppVeyor for Windows builds again, as there wouldn't be a perf hit.
- People building via Visual Studio can build using the release config and get the same perf as everybody else.
- Whatever minor benefits compiler optimizations would enable are applied.

There is of course still a small risk this could introduce desyncs somehow, so we should do some testing before moving forward.

data.title: LocalOffset doesn't work correct in TS viewing angle
data.body:
It looks like OpenRA doesn't use the right viewing angle for LocalOffset. I tested the same unit with the same settings in the RA mod - result was that the offset was 100% correct while in TS I got this result:
![localoffset](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12551040/7843405/c5499b2a-04a9-11e5-9752-34a9b616878d.png)

data.title: Use the new lua UserInterface in the missions
Lint rule to check actor upgrades
data.body: https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/wiki/Actor-Upgrades can't be checked at compile time. String types of several independent traits have to match. This is error prone as typos can occur and there will be no warning just silent breakage. A rule could add checks against unused `UpgradeTypes` or undefined `Upgrades` and spit out a warning which may catch at least some sloppy yaml mistakes early.

data.title: Fix Nod attacking the world in gdi05b
data.body: Fixes #8263

data.title: Write a lint rule to verify death types.
data.body: To prevent bugs like #8266.

data.title: Write a lint rule to verify system player stances
data.body: All maps should have a Neutral actor that defines OwnsWorld: true and has no allies or enemies.  Maps that define a Creeps player should have them enemy to everyone.  This will prevent any new bugs like #8263.
